newsitem.title: USA: Netscape, Sun in Java tools pact.
newsitem.headline: Netscape, Sun in Java tools pact.

text.p: Sun Microsystems Inc and Netscape Communications Corp said Wednesday they had agreed to jointly develop the Java Foundation Classes, a set of tools for defining the look and feel of Java applications.
The companies said International Business Machines Corp will contribute development support for this initiative.
No financial details of the pact were disclosed.

The Java tools use Sun's Java Abstract Windowing Toolkit as well as new tools. They also use the Netscape Windowing Internet Foundation Classes for a unified framework for Java application development.
Java is a computer language developed by Sun that enables software based on it to run across a variety of computer platforms that would otherwise be incompatible.

"This new effort folds Netscape's IFC technology into the Java standard and sets a clear path for Java developers," said Rick Schell, senior vice president of client and platform products division at Netscape.

"With the Java Foundation Classes, developers can quickly build crossware applications in Java for intranets and extranets that run across platforms, databases and networks and are accessible by users on the more than 50 million copies of Netscape client software," he said.
The new Java Foundation Classes are scheduled to be available in the next release of the Java Development Kit.
